thread.title: A nutritionist rates the best and worst packaged snacks
thread.title_full: A nutritionist rates the best and worst packaged snacks

title: A nutritionist rates the best and worst packaged snacks

organizations.name: happy snack food company faava beans  fruit

text:
A nutritionist rates the best and worst packaged snacks February 14, 2017 1:18pm Share on Twitter 
IF YOU are one of the people who makes your own trail mix and low sugar protein balls to munch on during the day, hats off to you. 
A more common scenario is one that sees us grab some type of packaged snack on our weekly trip to the supermarket to keep on hand for when the munchies strike. 
So which are the best options nutritionally if you do turn to a packaged snack food? A portion-controlled trail mix with lots of nuts and seeds is a good snack option. Source: Getty Images 
THE BEST 
A nutritionally balanced snack food will offer a mix of unrefined carbohydrate and protein, to keep us full for at least a couple of hours. For the average adult, a snack should be between 150-200 calories, with ingredients you know and recognise. Most importantly, you want it to taste good! 
Cheese and crackers 
Let’s be honest, who doesn’t love a cheese and cracker!? 
The simple combo of a portion controlled serve of calcium-rich cheese along with a few crackers, offers a great mix of carbs and protein. 
Best brand: Mainland Light Cheese and Crackers 
Nut Bars 
Yes, you can reach for a handful of nuts and a piece of fruit, but the great thing about a nut-based snack bar is that it is portion controlled. It can be made from a variety of different nuts and contain up to 10g of protein per serve. 
Best brands: Go Natural Nut Delight, Carman’s Nut Bars, Uncle Toby’s Nut Bars 
Roasted Broadbeans 
Forget potato chips. These simple, flavoured broadbeans are a great source of fibre and protein and taste so good, you will not even realise they are not chips. 
Best brand : Happy Snack Food Company Faava Beans 
Fruit and Nut Snacks 
Dried fruit is notoriously high in sugars, as are many commercial trail mixes. But if you get the right mix of seeds and nuts in a portion controlled pack, you get the right mix of carbs, proteins and good fats to keep you full for a few hours. 
Best brand: MUNCH Pumpkin Seeds 
Protein Balls 
While some low carb and low sugar products can be packed with different types of sugar, fats and less than nutritious additives, there are a few brands with relatively clean ingredient lists, which offer both a good source of carbs and proteins in a tasty, calorie-controlled snack. Arnotts Tiny Teddy biscuits. Source: News Limited 
THE WORST 
Biscuits 
Small packets of biscuits may look relatively plain, but the truth is they are most likely made from sugar, white flour and vegetable oil. With literally no protein or fibre, there is not a lot of positive things to say about plain biscuits. 
Worst brands: Tiny Teddies, Shapes 
Rice Crackers 
With high GI refined rice, oils and flavours including MSG among the primary ingredients, not only is it exceptionally easy to overeat these crunchy morsels, but they offer literally nothing positive nutritionally 
Worst brands: Sakata , Fantastic Snacks 
Muesli Slices 
When a snack is described as having a muesli base, it can be easily interpreted as a relatively healthy option. But a number of commercial products are packed full of sugars, oil and refined flour with very little muesli at all. They tend to be packed full of calories with up to 400 calories (or a meal) per serve. 
Worst brand: Mother Earth chocolate and apricot bars 
Noodle snacks 
This is another snack food that looks relatively simple. But a closer look at the ingredient list can show a mix of flavours, additives, salts and refined starches, which are good for no one, especially small children. 
Worst brand: Mamee Monster Noodle snacks 
Snack bars 
The range of snack bars available in supermarkets is wide and constantly growing, which makes it difficult to make nutritionally sound choices. In general, plain snack bars are processed, contain a range of added sugars and flavours with very little fibre or protein to help keep you full. They are best left as party food or left out of the shopping trolley completely.
